regulation.title: Occupational Safety and Health Standards - Exit Routes and Emergency Planning
regulation.applies_to: workplaces in general industry except mobile workplaces such as vehicles or vessels

rules.text: This section lists the sections and paragraph headings contained in §§ 1910.34 through 1910.39.
rules.requirement: reference sections 1910.34 through 1910.39 for applicable requirements

rules.text: Sections 1910.34 through 1910.39 apply to workplaces in general industry except mobile workplaces such as vehicles or vessels.
rules.requirement: comply with exit route requirements for general industry workplaces

items.description: mobile workplaces such as vehicles or vessels

rules.text: Electroluminescent means a light-emitting capacitor. Alternating current excites phosphor atoms when placed between the electrically conductive surfaces to produce light.
rules.requirement: understand electroluminescent light source definition for exit lighting

rules.text: Occupant load means the total number of persons that may occupy a workplace or portion of a workplace at any one time. The occupant load of a workplace is calculated by dividing the gross floor area of the workplace or portion of the workplace by the occupant load factor for that particular type of workplace occupancy.
rules.requirement: calculate occupant load using gross floor area divided by occupant load factor

rules.text: Refuge area means either: (1) A space along an exit route that is protected from the effects of fire by separation from other spaces within the building by a barrier with at least a one-hour fire resistance-rating; or (2) A floor with at least two spaces, separated from each other by smoke-resistant partitions, in a building protected throughout by an automatic sprinkler system that complies with § 1910.159 of this part.
rules.requirement: provide refuge areas with one-hour fire resistance rating or sprinkler-protected spaces with smoke-resistant partitions

rules.text: OSHA will deem an employer demonstrating compliance with the exit-route provisions of NFPA 101, Life Safety Code, 2009 edition, or the exit-route provisions of the International Fire Code, 2009 edition, to be in compliance with the corresponding requirements in §§ 1910.34, 1910.36, and 1910.37.
rules.requirement: comply with NFPA 101-2009 or IFC-2009 exit route provisions as alternative compliance method

sections.title: Design and construction requirements for exit routes

rules.text: An exit route must be permanent. Each exit route must be a permanent part of the workplace.
rules.requirement: ensure exit routes are permanent parts of the workplace

rules.text: An exit must be separated by fire resistant materials. Construction materials used to separate an exit from other parts of the workplace must have a one-hour fire resistance-rating if the exit connects three or fewer stories and a two-hour fire resistance-rating if the exit connects four or more stories.
rules.requirement: separate exits with fire resistant materials based on number of stories connected

rules.text: Openings into an exit must be limited. An exit is permitted to have only those openings necessary to allow access to the exit from occupied areas of the workplace, or to the exit discharge. An opening into an exit must be protected by a self-closing fire door that remains closed or automatically closes in an emergency upon the sounding of a fire alarm or employee alarm system.
rules.requirement: limit exit openings to necessary access points and protect with self-closing fire doors

rules.text: At least two exit routes must be available in a workplace to permit prompt evacuation of employees and other building occupants during an emergency, except as allowed in paragraph (b)(3) of this section.
rules.requirement: provide at least two exit routes located as far away as practical from each other

items.description: as allowed in paragraph (b)(3) for single exit route

rules.text: More than two exit routes must be available in a workplace if the number of employees, the size of the building, its occupancy, or the arrangement of the workplace is such that all employees would not be able to evacuate safely during an emergency.
rules.requirement: provide more than two exit routes when needed for safe evacuation based on occupancy factors

rules.text: A single exit route is permitted where the number of employees, the size of the building, its occupancy, or the arrangement of the workplace is such that all employees would be able to evacuate safely during an emergency.
rules.requirement: single exit route permitted only when all employees can evacuate safely

rules.text: Each exit discharge must lead directly outside or to a street, walkway, refuge area, public way, or open space with access to the outside.
rules.requirement: ensure exit discharge leads directly to safe exterior location

rules.text: The street, walkway, refuge area, public way, or open space to which an exit discharge leads must be large enough to accommodate the building occupants likely to use the exit route.
rules.requirement: size discharge areas to accommodate expected building occupants

rules.text: Employees must be able to open an exit route door from the inside at all times without keys, tools, or special knowledge. A device such as a panic bar that locks only from the outside is permitted on exit discharge doors.
rules.requirement: ensure exit doors can be opened from inside without keys, tools, or special knowledge

items.description: panic bar that locks only from outside on exit discharge doors
mental, penal, or correctional facilities with supervisory personnel

rules.text: Exit route doors must be free of any device or alarm that could restrict emergency use of the exit route if the device or alarm fails.
rules.requirement: ensure exit route doors remain usable if devices or alarms fail

rules.text: A side-hinged door must be used to connect any room to an exit route.
rules.requirement: use side-hinged doors for all room connections to exit routes

rules.text: The door that connects any room to an exit route must swing out in the direction of exit travel if the room is designed to be occupied by more than 50 people or if the room is a high hazard area.
rules.requirement: ensure doors swing outward for rooms with 50+ occupants or high hazard areas
rules.applies_to: large occupancy rooms and high hazard areas

rules.text: Exit routes must support the maximum permitted occupant load for each floor served.
rules.requirement: size exit routes to support maximum permitted occupant load

rules.text: The capacity of an exit route may not decrease in the direction of exit route travel to the exit discharge.
rules.requirement: maintain or increase exit route capacity toward exit discharge

rules.text: The ceiling of an exit route must be at least seven feet six inches (2.3 m) high. Any projection from the ceiling must not reach a point less than six feet eight inches (2.0 m) from the floor.
rules.requirement: maintain minimum ceiling height of 7 feet 6 inches with projections not below 6 feet 8 inches

rules.text: An exit access must be at least 28 inches (71.1 cm) wide at all points. Where there is only one exit access leading to an exit or exit discharge, the width of the exit and exit discharge must be at least equal to the width of the exit access.
rules.requirement: maintain minimum width of 28 inches for exit access with matching exit widths

rules.text: The width of an exit route must be sufficient to accommodate the maximum permitted occupant load of each floor served by the exit route.
rules.requirement: size exit route width based on maximum permitted occupant load

rules.text: Objects that project into the exit route must not reduce the width of the exit route to less than the minimum width requirements for exit routes.
rules.requirement: prevent objects from reducing exit route width below minimum requirements

rules.text: The outdoor exit route must have guardrails to protect unenclosed sides if a fall hazard exists.
rules.requirement: install guardrails on outdoor exit routes where fall hazards exist
rules.applies_to: outdoor exit routes with fall hazards

rules.text: The outdoor exit route must be covered if snow or ice is likely to accumulate along the route, unless the employer can demonstrate that any snow or ice accumulation will be removed before it presents a slipping hazard.
rules.requirement: cover outdoor exit routes or remove snow/ice accumulation to prevent slipping hazards
rules.applies_to: outdoor exit routes in snow/ice climates

items.description: employer demonstrates snow/ice removal before slipping hazard

rules.text: The outdoor exit route must not have a dead-end that is longer than 20 feet (6.2 m).
rules.requirement: limit outdoor exit route dead-ends to maximum 20 feet

sections.title: Maintenance, safeguards, and operational features for exit routes

rules.text: Exit routes must be kept free of explosive or highly flammable furnishings or other decorations.
rules.requirement: prohibit explosive or highly flammable furnishings and decorations in exit routes

rules.text: Exit routes must be free and unobstructed. No materials or equipment may be placed, either permanently or temporarily, within the exit route. The exit access must not go through a room that can be locked, such as a bathroom, to reach an exit or exit discharge, nor may it lead into a dead-end corridor.
rules.requirement: maintain unobstructed exit routes without materials, equipment, or lockable rooms in path
rules.applies_to: all exit routes and exit access

rules.text: Each exit route must be adequately lighted so that an employee with normal vision can see along the exit route.
rules.requirement: provide adequate lighting for normal vision along entire exit route

rules.text: Each exit must be clearly visible and marked by a sign reading 'Exit.'
rules.requirement: mark each exit with clearly visible 'Exit' sign

rules.text: Each exit sign must be illuminated to a surface value of at least five foot-candles (54 lux) by a reliable light source and be distinctive in color. Self-luminous or electroluminescent signs that have a minimum luminance surface value of at least .06 footlamberts (0.21 cd/m2) are permitted.
rules.requirement: illuminate exit signs to minimum 5 foot-candles or use self-luminous signs with 0.06 footlamberts minimum

rules.text: Each exit sign must have the word 'Exit' in plainly legible letters not less than six inches (15.2 cm) high, with the principal strokes of the letters in the word 'Exit' not less than three-fourths of an inch (1.9 cm) wide.
rules.requirement: size exit sign letters minimum 6 inches high with strokes minimum 3/4 inch wide

rules.text: During new construction, employees must not occupy a workplace until the exit routes required by this subpart are completed and ready for employee use for the portion of the workplace they occupy.
rules.requirement: complete exit routes before allowing employee occupancy during new construction

rules.text: During repairs or alterations, employees must not occupy a workplace unless the exit routes required by this subpart are available and existing fire protections are maintained, or until alternate fire protection is furnished that provides an equivalent level of safety.
rules.requirement: maintain required exit routes and fire protections during repairs/alterations or provide equivalent alternatives

rules.text: Employers must install and maintain an operable employee alarm system that has a distinctive signal to warn employees of fire or other emergencies, unless employees can promptly see or smell a fire or other hazard in time to provide adequate warning to them. The employee alarm system must comply with § 1910.165.
rules.requirement: install and maintain operable employee alarm system with distinctive signals unless natural detection is adequate

items.description: employees can promptly see or smell fire/hazards for adequate warning

rules.text: An employer must have an emergency action plan whenever an OSHA standard in this part requires one. The requirements in this section apply to each such emergency action plan.
rules.requirement: develop emergency action plan when required by OSHA standards

conditions.parameter: OSHA standard requires emergency action plan

subsections.title: Written and oral emergency action plans

rules.text: An emergency action plan must be in writing, kept in the workplace, and available to employees for review. However, an employer with 10 or fewer employees may communicate the plan orally to employees.
rules.requirement: maintain written emergency action plan available for employee review, or oral communication for 10 or fewer employees
rules.applies_to: all employers with emergency action plans

items.description: employer with 10 or fewer employees may communicate plan orally

subsections.title: Minimum elements of emergency action plan

rules.text: Procedures for reporting a fire or other emergency.
rules.requirement: establish procedures for reporting fires and other emergencies

rules.text: Procedures for emergency evacuation, including type of evacuation and exit route assignments.
rules.requirement: establish emergency evacuation procedures with evacuation types and exit route assignments

rules.text: Procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate.
rules.requirement: establish procedures for employees operating critical systems before evacuation

rules.text: Procedures to account for all employees after evacuation.
rules.requirement: establish procedures to account for all employees after evacuation

rules.text: Procedures to be followed by employees performing rescue or medical duties.
rules.requirement: establish procedures for employees performing rescue or medical duties

conditions.parameter: employees assigned rescue or medical duties

rules.text: The name or job title of every employee who may be contacted by employees who need more information about the plan or an explanation of their duties under the plan.
rules.requirement: identify contact persons for plan information and duty explanations

rules.text: An employer must have and maintain an employee alarm system. The employee alarm system must use a distinctive signal for each purpose and comply with the requirements in § 1910.165.
rules.requirement: maintain employee alarm system with distinctive signals for each purpose complying with § 1910.165
rules.applies_to: all employers with emergency action plans

rules.text: An employer must designate and train employees to assist in a safe and orderly evacuation of other employees.
rules.requirement: designate and train employees to assist in safe and orderly evacuations
rules.applies_to: all employers with emergency action plans

rules.text: When the plan is developed or the employee is assigned initially to a job.
rules.requirement: review emergency action plan when developed or employee initially assigned
rules.applies_to: all employees covered by emergency action plans

rules.text: When the employee's responsibilities under the plan change.
rules.requirement: review emergency action plan when employee responsibilities change

rules.text: When the plan is changed.
rules.requirement: review emergency action plan with employees when plan is changed

rules.text: An employer must have a fire prevention plan when an OSHA standard in this part requires one. The requirements in this section apply to each such fire prevention plan.
rules.requirement: develop fire prevention plan when required by OSHA standards

conditions.parameter: OSHA standard requires fire prevention plan

subsections.title: Written and oral fire prevention plans

rules.text: A fire prevention plan must be in writing, be kept in the workplace, and be made available to employees for review. However, an employer with 10 or fewer employees may communicate the plan orally to employees.
rules.requirement: maintain written fire prevention plan available for employee review, or oral communication for 10 or fewer employees
rules.applies_to: all employers with fire prevention plans

items.description: employer with 10 or fewer employees may communicate plan orally

subsections.title: Minimum elements of fire prevention plan

rules.text: A list of all major fire hazards, proper handling and storage procedures for hazardous materials, potential ignition sources and their control, and the type of fire protection equipment necessary to control each major hazard.
rules.requirement: identify major fire hazards, handling procedures, ignition sources, and required fire protection equipment

rules.text: Procedures to control accumulations of flammable and combustible waste materials.
rules.requirement: establish procedures to control flammable and combustible waste accumulations

rules.text: Procedures for regular maintenance of safeguards installed on heat-producing equipment to prevent the accidental ignition of combustible materials.
rules.requirement: establish regular maintenance procedures for heat-producing equipment safeguards

rules.text: The name or job title of employees responsible for maintaining equipment to prevent or control sources of ignition or fires.
rules.requirement: identify employees responsible for maintaining ignition control and fire prevention equipment

rules.text: The name or job title of employees responsible for the control of fuel source hazards.
rules.requirement: identify employees responsible for controlling fuel source hazards

rules.text: An employer must inform employees upon initial assignment to a job of the fire hazards to which they are exposed. An employer must also review with each employee those parts of the fire prevention plan necessary for self-protection.
rules.requirement: inform employees of fire hazards upon initial assignment and review relevant fire prevention plan elements
rules.applies_to: all employees in workplaces with fire prevention plans
